VOL. XLIV No. 13

Mitchell
reception
May 14
With the farewell reception for
Dr Broadus Mitchell only ten days
away, a committee of forty students
yesterday launched its drive to bring
out students and alumni for a final
tribute to the Hopkins economist,
whose resignation was recently announced. The reception will be held
in Levering hall between 8 and 10
o'clock on Sunday night, May 14,. Invitations have been extended to "all"
friends of Dr Mitchell.
The organizations sponsoring the
affair are: Omicron Delta Kappa,
the Student council, the Liberal club,
the American Student union, the
NEWS-LETTER, and the Musical club.
Carrington Williams, president-elect
of the Student council, is executive
secretary of the committee.
In announcing plans for the reception, Williams laid emphasis on
its spontaneity.
"A program to honor Broadus
Mitchell," he said, "certainly needs
no advertisement.
We are doing
everything possible to make the
party as unstaged and informal as
possible. Our only purpose is to give
the campus and the community an
opportunity to pay tribute to one
of its most stimulating and beloved
instructors."
The resignation of Dr Mitchell
from the Homewood faculty has been
an occasion for the expression of
public regret from student organizations almost unparalleled in the University's history. Up until last night,
ten organizations, including Omicron
Delta Kappa, the Tudor and _Stnart
fraternities,

Clarification
The story is last week's NEWS-,ETTER concerning a reception to
be held for Dr Broadus Mitchell
misrepresented the facts. The
NEWS-LETTER feels a clarification
is necessary.
Petitions for reappointment of
Dr Mitchell are not a part of the
Reception committee's work. The
headline, "Mitchell resignation provokes action," did not properly describe the origin of reception plans.
The committee is interested only
in showing Dr Mitchell in what
high regard it holds for him for his
work at the University, the group
believes.
Finally, "The
Help Mitchell
committee" is not the name of the
group, nor does this name properly
describe its work.
A correct and more complete
story appears in the column to the
left.

Speaking on the subject "Democracy and Industrial Relations" Mary
van Kleeck brought to a close the
current University Supper club lecture series. Miss van Kleeck is a nationality prominent edonomist and
sociologist.
In her address Miss van Kleeck
pointed out that concentration of
control of and un-democratic distribution are the reasons for the present
imperfect functioning of business.
Beginning with the thesis that "the
real conditions on which economics
are based are always in a process of
evolution", she stated that "the test
of the value of any economic system
was the degree of development of all
possible resources, both human and
physical, for the betterment of the
conditions of the people living under
the system."
With concentration of control such
as exists in present day business
democratic control is impossible."
"The present problems which the
United states faces do not constitute
an insurmountable obstacle in the
path of economic recovery," Miss
van Kleeck said.
"Our problems no longer lie in
scarcity but in the organization of a
great wealth of new resources and improvements. We must face in a democratic way this reality and adapt
our economic system to it."

last week is set to bring to the Hopkins a promising young band with
new ideas on the popular musical
trend, which he calls blues and considers a reaction to the raging swing
fests.
"Swing is on the wane," says this
young band leader whose band has
only been playing together for
two
and a half years. The orchestra
was
organized on a cooperative basis, all
the members in the band have a
part
interest which accounts for their

concerned.

Professors
Drs Dieke and Bearden were
promoted to the position of professors in physics last Tuesday
when the Board of trustees approved the change suggested by
the academic council. Both men
have been associated with the
Hopkins for ten years, successively taking the positions of
associate and then associate professorships.
Dr Dieke received degrees at
Linden in 1923 and 1925, when
he became a fellow at the University of California Institute
of Technology, University of
Tokyo, and the University of
Cronigan.
Dr Bearden holds degrees from
Furman University and Chicago,
where he was a member of the
teaching staff until 1929, when
he accepted a position at the
Hopkins.

FRIDAY, MAY 5, 1939

There is no mistaking it.
The campus has grown
tense. Fabulous rumors of
resignations and counterresignations have fallen like
sparks on the tinder-box.
Ignited by Dr Mitchell's
announcement of his departure the fires of student
disappointment and unrest were fed by subsequent
resignations and were reflected in the Evening Sun's
editorial suggesting the intellectual decline of the
University.
Coming at the height of this restlessness, the
editorial which the NEWS-LETTER printed in these
columns last week was taken by many as an attempt
to sandbag the drive to keep Dr Mitchell.
Vigorously do we wish to correct this impression.
We cannot accept the idea that Johns Hopkins is a
dying center of learning, and our disagreement with
the Sun came over the projection of Dr Mitchell's loss
into long range terms.

In its main thesis, therefore, the NEWS-LETTER gives
the Evening Sun unquestioned support. Dr Mitchell
should be retained, if that is at all possible.
Following the example of numerous other organizations, the NEWS-LETTER will go on record this
week for his reappointment. A resolution to this
effect will be forwarded to the administration, and
this paper will continue to support the campus's
loyalty to one of its great figures and its friend.

It takes more than just a
little investigation to find
anything of value in the new
rushing agreement among
a Ii fraternities on t h e
campus. A hasty survey
seems to indicate that intangible desires of principle have been satisfied and
that fraternity relations are headed for a rosy future
based on a gentlemen's agreement. But just where this
is important we fail to see.
True, Jewish fraternities now have delayed rushing rules. And some attempt has been made to join
two groups which have common ground and which
would have been joined years ago but for certain pressure on the Interfraternity board. The least that will
come out of the understanding will be unified rushing rules for all fraternities, Jewish and non-Jewish

Point
of
Departure

alike.
But a split has developed already. One group on
the Board wants enforcement of rushing rules divided
between two groups, one to take care of the Jewish
houses and another to judge violations by non-Jewish
fraternities. This, of course, would wreck all plans
of interfraternity unity from the start. Since the rushing agreement is valuable only as a point of departure, any attempt to quash unified control of rushing
makes the agreement a failure from the start.
The only value of the agreement per se lies in its
improvement of inter-fraternity organization. The intangibles of inter-fraternity unity have not been given
much of a push forward, but the rushing agreement
points the way. And the way seems to lead to a real
Inter-fraternity board, i e, a board which represents
all fraternities on the campus.
The advantages of such a real Inter-fraternity
board will be obscure only to those who want to obscure it. All fraternities, no matter on which side
of the artificial fence now erected they fall, have
common problems which could best be solved by

an Interfraternity board representing all fraternities.
Doubts are certainly raised by splits in the rushing agreement, the very fundamental consideration of
the bare beginnings of inter-fraternity unity, hence
our slightly less than pessimistic outlook. And consequently we see little value in the agreement itself.
But if this move on the part of the Inter-fraternity
board and the Student council manifiests a trend, it
is valuable. If not, it has little value to the Jewish
fraternities, still less to the non-Jewish fraternities
and none at all to inter-fraternity unity.

Reviews and Previews
Last Saturday evening we had the
pleasure of witnessing a real actress
at the Stanley theater. Bette Davis,
as the young woman who fears
death and yet knows she has but
several months to live, gives a stirring performance in "Dark Victory."
She succeeds in conveying to the
audience the fright of pending death.
Aside from Miss Davis, there is little
to mention. The plot is not particularily strong inasmuch as it arrives
at no end. It does not have a great
deal of suspense nor an abundance
of interesting twists. The rest of
the cast also turn in splendid performances, but their roles do not re-

quire unusual skill. It was intended
to be a 'one star picture' and that,
it is.

Personality Parade
In the eyes of all who know him, a
short, pop-eyed comedian with nine
daughters is still the greatest fellow
on the stage today. This gentleman,
who is as popular at present as he
was twenty years ago, is none other
than Eddie Cantor. Eddie has continued to grow in the public's admiration at a time when the big
names of the last decade are fading
into obscurity. The reason for his
has
popularity
is
obvious. He
changed from a comedian to a
symbol of something far greater; he
is the spirit of Americanism. Not
once in his entire career has scandal
ever arisen about him, and if ever a
man was in position to cause talk it
was Eddie,playing in the Follies
night after night for years with the
most gorgeous girls in the world
about him. Never has he resorted to
profanity or filth during the many
years he has been on the radio.

College Miscellany

The World

From a 11 indications,
compulsary assemblies are
still not a beloved part of
the Hopkins tradition. Then
why have them?
Let a committee, appointby the Council, look into
the matter. If the freshmen (or other men) want to
attend voluntary interesting assemblies, which we
seriously doubt, set up such a plan. If not, by all
means, don't push a sore point to no good end.
Out with them!
The question is not such an intricate one as to
require too much debate. Let's treat it for what it's
worth and not be silly about it. The Council is called
upon for prompt decisive action next year.

Juniors will extend themselves for their last pre-exam

enough sense to prevent a
recurrence of last year's financial catastrophe.
We still maintain that there is no reason why
finances should remain the bane of class officers' existences. We have proposed in these columns twice, at
least, financial schemes for insuring the success of a
social season. Here is a decent problem for the B S A
to contend with.
You've really got to hand
it to Grover Whalen.
When he does something, he
does it right, and we do
mean the New York World's
fair.
For about three months
now, we've been deluged by an outpouring of offerings—from locomotive to bathing beauty—described
wholly in superlatives and which, intended for the
public eye, were destined to the trash box. But the
fair is not to be treated lightly. It is gaudy and
spectacular; it is flashy and cheap; it is an education
and a side show—but like Carl Sandburg's broadshouldered Chicago, it is America.
From its wierd motifs, garish colors, and its great
hodge-podge of machinery and displays, to its huge
cost, it spells the progress and vitality and lack of
convention of a century and a half of American life.
The fair should be a rich experience in reawakened
interest. Americans, smug in the conviction that they
are members of an enviable Colossus, little realize its
full significance. Everyone should have the opportunity to see the fair.
Millions will get this opportunity and will come
away tired and dazed, but with new light in their eyes,
and new hope and inspiration in their breasis. The
time is a propitious one for contrast with other nations. Let the World's fair be a symbol of what can
be done and is done here, and only here.

Injury-riddled Jays revive

The Blue Jay lacrosse team will
journey north to meet the Orange
and Black of Princeton tomorrow.
With five wins over regular opponents and one over BAC in a practice
game and one defeat, the Black and
Blue have yet to win a major victory.
So far this season Princeton has
yet to win its first game. This cannot be a discredit to the team however, for her losses have been at the
hands of Mt Washington, BAC,
Navy, and Maryland. The experience
that she gained cannot be overestimated.
An interesting fact about the New
Jersey aggregation is that five of
the starting ten are Baltimoreans,
Andy Taylor and Joe King from
Boys Latin School play on the close
attack, Billy Lynn from Gilman is
at second attack; Henry Thomas
from Gilman plays defense; and
Bucky Turner, also from Gilman,
takes care of the nets. Five or six
more local boys are on the squad.
All of the first five named with the
exception of Thomas were former
All State prep school stars.
The Blue Jays are pointing for
this game, and the coaching staff,
Mallonee,
and
Morrill,
Messrs.
Schmeisser have been working the
whole squad very hard. It is problematical whether four regulars,
Nicholson, Spilman, Nance, and
Buck, will be able to play. Of the
four, Nance has the best chance. In
has
Morrill
meantime, Dr
the
switched Dick Green from center to
out home and brought up Charles
Thomas for the inhome position in
order to complete with John Enders
the close attack. Bob Gosnell filled in
the center position and Jack
Williams replaced Buck on the defense. Despite the fact that these
injuries have riddled the attack, recent scrimmages have not shown any
decrease in its power.
Offsetting the news of injuries
came the information that John
Tolson, JHU All American of 1938,
has returned to action. He will be
able to play five minutes in each
quarter against Princeton, a little
more time per quarter against St
Johns, and the whole game against
Maryland. Because he is not in shape
and has not worked with the defense, his presence in the line-up
may not increase its strength a
great deal. But the last two games
he will have the condition and will
have been accustomed to this defense. Freddy Buck and Rip Hewitt
please note.

Varsity softballers
shut-out Maryland
The J H U varsity softball team
played its first game of the season
Tuesday aftrenoon at College Park,
Md, where they shut out the U of
Maryland, 6-0. The team is composed
of both fraternity and non-fraternity
men.
The battlers for the Jays found M
Cord on the mound and Pressman on
the receiving end. Robinson, first
base; Rossett, second base; Fehr,
short stop, and Sullivan, third base,
rounded out the infield while Butt,
Zavertnick and Grey patroled the
outfield.
The Jays got off to an early tworun lead in the first and added one in
the third, two more in the fourth, and
their final tally came in the fifth.
The Marylanders could do very
little with the slants of McCord,
whose fast ball and change of pace
kept the opposing batters off balance. McCord pitched no hit, no run
ball until the seventh, when with one
out he let up and allowed the one
and only hit of the game off him.
His mates gave him good support
and hit hard and often to win .he
game handily.
The next varsity softball game
will be played tomorrow at Homewood against George Washington U.

Speaking
150 students, the largest audience
ever to assemble in Levering hall's
Sherwood room in the memory of
undergraduates, Dr Broadus Mitchell
urged Hopkins students to investigate and judge social conditions for
themselves.
Only the individual work of students, he stressed, can be of value in
the nation's future progress. While
orthodox material and opinions may
be studied by the student, he declared
they should serve only as a general
background of knowledge.
This was one of Dr Mitchell's last
public appearances in connection with
the university. He resigned his post
of professor of economics last month,
thus ending a quarter-century career with the Hopkins.
Dr Mitchell traced the evolution of
higher education in America in its
broad general trends. Beginning with
the founding of the Hopkins in 1867,
he emphasized that private colleges
and universities were in the liberal
vanguard then, while the state-supported institutions struggled for existence.

The banquet was tendered in honor
Lt Col Greggory H Hoisington, who
is leaving the military department
in June for foreign service. He has
been professor of miltary science
and tactics since 1934, returning to
the department which he had headed
from 1923 to 1928.
A lifetime pen and stand with
chromium plating was presented
to Col Hoisington by Schmied. The
colonel made a farewell speech, expressing sorrow "at leaving such an
intelligent, friendly group of students."
Col Hoisington graduated from
West Point in 1911.
Other new officers include Douglas
Spencer, lieutenant; Thomas Schreiber, 2nd lieutenant; Jerry Carleton,
1st sergeant.
Lt Frank H Forney was inducted
as an associate member.

Amos and Andy; and the outstand-

"For a' that, an' a' that,
It's comm n yet for a' that,
That man to man the world o'er
Shall brithers be for a' that."
Thus spoke Bobby Burns at the
dawn of the 19th century, little realizing that 143 years after his death
there was to come into the world an
instrument, a great invention, that
will do more to make men all over the
world brothers than the spirit of his
own "man to man" poetry. Television is that great invention and
fittingly it was inaugurated in this
country at the City of Tomorrow with
the address of our President.
In these shivering times it's mighty
hard to conceive of anything making
men feel like brothers. The radio
might have done it, but the voice is
not enough to establish a real contact with a foreigner; you just give
him a look at you, let him see that
you're not much different than he is
and pretty soon he'll begin to understand you. Before television, all he
could hear was some gibberish tongue
which more than likely sounded distasteful to him, but once he sees you

moving around, though he doesn't understand what you have to say, your
actions will speak for themselves.
This cub reporter hopes that television will broaden the vision of peace
rather than merely view the war
abroad!

Mitchell
reception
May 14
With the farewell reception for
Dr Broadus Mitchell only ten days
away, a committee of forty students
yesterday launched its drive to bring
out students and alumni for a final
tribute to the Hopkins economist,
whose resignation was recently announced. The reception will be held
in Levering hall between 8 and 10
o'clock on Sunday night, May 14,. Invitations have been extended to "all"
friends of Dr Mitchell.
The organizations sponsoring the
affair are: Omicron Delta Kappa,
the Student council, the Liberal club,
the American Student union, the
NEWS-LETTER, and the Musical club.
Carrington Williams, president-elect
of the Student council, is executive
secretary of the committee.
In announcing plans for the reception, Williams laid emphasis on
its spontaneity.
"A program to honor Broadus
Mitchell," he said, "certainly needs
no advertisement.
We are doing
everything possible to make the
party as unstaged and informal as
possible. Our only purpose is to give
the campus and the community an
opportunity to pay tribute to one
of its most stimulating and beloved
instructors."
The resignation of Dr Mitchell
from the Homewood faculty has been
an occasion for the expression of
public regret from student organizations almost unparalleled in the University's history. Up until last night,
ten organizations, including Omicron
Delta Kappa, the Tudor and _Stnart
fraternities,

Clarification
The story is last week's NEWS-,ETTER concerning a reception to
be held for Dr Broadus Mitchell
misrepresented the facts. The
NEWS-LETTER feels a clarification
is necessary.
Petitions for reappointment of
Dr Mitchell are not a part of the
Reception committee's work. The
headline, "Mitchell resignation provokes action," did not properly describe the origin of reception plans.
The committee is interested only
in showing Dr Mitchell in what
high regard it holds for him for his
work at the University, the group
believes.
Finally, "The
Help Mitchell
committee" is not the name of the
group, nor does this name properly
describe its work.
A correct and more complete
story appears in the column to the
left.

Speaking on the subject "Democracy and Industrial Relations" Mary
van Kleeck brought to a close the
current University Supper club lecture series. Miss van Kleeck is a nationality prominent edonomist and
sociologist.
In her address Miss van Kleeck
pointed out that concentration of
control of and un-democratic distribution are the reasons for the present
imperfect functioning of business.
Beginning with the thesis that "the
real conditions on which economics
are based are always in a process of
evolution", she stated that "the test
of the value of any economic system
was the degree of development of all
possible resources, both human and
physical, for the betterment of the
conditions of the people living under
the system."
With concentration of control such
as exists in present day business
democratic control is impossible."
"The present problems which the
United states faces do not constitute
an insurmountable obstacle in the
path of economic recovery," Miss
van Kleeck said.
"Our problems no longer lie in
scarcity but in the organization of a
great wealth of new resources and improvements. We must face in a democratic way this reality and adapt
our economic system to it."

Professors
Drs Dieke and Bearden were
promoted to the position of professors in physics last Tuesday
when the Board of trustees approved the change suggested by
the academic council. Both men
have been associated with the
Hopkins for ten years, successively taking the positions of
associate and then associate professorships.
Dr Dieke received degrees at
Linden in 1923 and 1925, when
he became a fellow at the University of California Institute
of Technology, University of
Tokyo, and the University of
Cronigan.
Dr Bearden holds degrees from
Furman University and Chicago,
where he was a member of the
teaching staff until 1929, when
he accepted a position at the
Hopkins.

FRIDAY, MAY 5, 1939

There is no mistaking it.
The campus has grown
tense. Fabulous rumors of
resignations and counterresignations have fallen like
sparks on the tinder-box.
Ignited by Dr Mitchell's
announcement of his departure the fires of student
disappointment and unrest were fed by subsequent
resignations and were reflected in the Evening Sun's
editorial suggesting the intellectual decline of the
University.
Coming at the height of this restlessness, the
editorial which the NEWS-LETTER printed in these
columns last week was taken by many as an attempt
to sandbag the drive to keep Dr Mitchell.
Vigorously do we wish to correct this impression.
We cannot accept the idea that Johns Hopkins is a
dying center of learning, and our disagreement with
the Sun came over the projection of Dr Mitchell's loss
into long range terms.

In its main thesis, therefore, the NEWS-LETTER gives
the Evening Sun unquestioned support. Dr Mitchell
should be retained, if that is at all possible.
Following the example of numerous other organizations, the NEWS-LETTER will go on record this
week for his reappointment. A resolution to this
effect will be forwarded to the administration, and
this paper will continue to support the campus's
loyalty to one of its great figures and its friend.

It takes more than just a
little investigation to find
anything of value in the new
rushing agreement among
a Ii fraternities on t h e
campus. A hasty survey
seems to indicate that intangible desires of principle have been satisfied and
that fraternity relations are headed for a rosy future
based on a gentlemen's agreement. But just where this
is important we fail to see.
True, Jewish fraternities now have delayed rushing rules. And some attempt has been made to join
two groups which have common ground and which
would have been joined years ago but for certain pressure on the Interfraternity board. The least that will
come out of the understanding will be unified rushing rules for all fraternities, Jewish and non-Jewish

Point
of
Departure

alike.
But a split has developed already. One group on
the Board wants enforcement of rushing rules divided
between two groups, one to take care of the Jewish
houses and another to judge violations by non-Jewish
fraternities. This, of course, would wreck all plans
of interfraternity unity from the start. Since the rushing agreement is valuable only as a point of departure, any attempt to quash unified control of rushing
makes the agreement a failure from the start.
The only value of the agreement per se lies in its
improvement of inter-fraternity organization. The intangibles of inter-fraternity unity have not been given
much of a push forward, but the rushing agreement
points the way. And the way seems to lead to a real
Inter-fraternity board, i e, a board which represents
all fraternities on the campus.
The advantages of such a real Inter-fraternity
board will be obscure only to those who want to obscure it. All fraternities, no matter on which side
of the artificial fence now erected they fall, have
common problems which could best be solved by

an Interfraternity board representing all fraternities.
Doubts are certainly raised by splits in the rushing agreement, the very fundamental consideration of
the bare beginnings of inter-fraternity unity, hence
our slightly less than pessimistic outlook. And consequently we see little value in the agreement itself.
But if this move on the part of the Inter-fraternity
board and the Student council manifiests a trend, it
is valuable. If not, it has little value to the Jewish
fraternities, still less to the non-Jewish fraternities
and none at all to inter-fraternity unity.

Reviews and Previews
Last Saturday evening we had the
pleasure of witnessing a real actress
at the Stanley theater. Bette Davis,
as the young woman who fears
death and yet knows she has but
several months to live, gives a stirring performance in "Dark Victory."
She succeeds in conveying to the
audience the fright of pending death.
Aside from Miss Davis, there is little
to mention. The plot is not particularily strong inasmuch as it arrives
at no end. It does not have a great
deal of suspense nor an abundance
of interesting twists. The rest of
the cast also turn in splendid performances, but their roles do not re-

quire unusual skill. It was intended
to be a 'one star picture' and that,
it is.

Personality Parade
In the eyes of all who know him, a
short, pop-eyed comedian with nine
daughters is still the greatest fellow
on the stage today. This gentleman,
who is as popular at present as he
was twenty years ago, is none other
than Eddie Cantor. Eddie has continued to grow in the public's admiration at a time when the big
names of the last decade are fading
into obscurity. The reason for his
has
popularity
is
obvious. He
changed from a comedian to a
symbol of something far greater; he
is the spirit of Americanism. Not
once in his entire career has scandal
ever arisen about him, and if ever a
man was in position to cause talk it
was Eddie,playing in the Follies
night after night for years with the
most gorgeous girls in the world
about him. Never has he resorted to
profanity or filth during the many
years he has been on the radio.

From a 11 indications,
compulsary assemblies are
still not a beloved part of
the Hopkins tradition. Then
why have them?
Let a committee, appointby the Council, look into
the matter. If the freshmen (or other men) want to
attend voluntary interesting assemblies, which we
seriously doubt, set up such a plan. If not, by all
means, don't push a sore point to no good end.
Out with them!
The question is not such an intricate one as to
require too much debate. Let's treat it for what it's
worth and not be silly about it. The Council is called
upon for prompt decisive action next year.

Juniors will extend themselves for their last pre-exam
session tomorrow night with
Glenn Miller's help. All we
hope is that the boys, while
enough sense to prevent a
recurrence of last year's financial catastrophe.
We still maintain that there is no reason why
finances should remain the bane of class officers' existences. We have proposed in these columns twice, at
least, financial schemes for insuring the success of a
social season. Here is a decent problem for the B S A
to contend with.
You've really got to hand
it to Grover Whalen.
When he does something, he
does it right, and we do
mean the New York World's
fair.
For about three months
now, we've been deluged by an outpouring of offerings—from locomotive to bathing beauty—described
wholly in superlatives and which, intended for the
public eye, were destined to the trash box. But the
fair is not to be treated lightly. It is gaudy and
spectacular; it is flashy and cheap; it is an education
and a side show—but like Carl Sandburg's broadshouldered Chicago, it is America.
From its wierd motifs, garish colors, and its great
hodge-podge of machinery and displays, to its huge
cost, it spells the progress and vitality and lack of
convention of a century and a half of American life.
The fair should be a rich experience in reawakened
interest. Americans, smug in the conviction that they
are members of an enviable Colossus, little realize its
full significance. Everyone should have the opportunity to see the fair.
Millions will get this opportunity and will come
away tired and dazed, but with new light in their eyes,
and new hope and inspiration in their breasis. The
time is a propitious one for contrast with other nations. Let the World's fair be a symbol of what can
be done and is done here, and only here.

Injury-riddled Jays revive

The Blue Jay lacrosse team will
journey north to meet the Orange
and Black of Princeton tomorrow.
With five wins over regular opponents and one over BAC in a practice
game and one defeat, the Black and
Blue have yet to win a major victory.
So far this season Princeton has
yet to win its first game. This cannot be a discredit to the team however, for her losses have been at the
hands of Mt Washington, BAC,
Navy, and Maryland. The experience
that she gained cannot be overestimated.
An interesting fact about the New
Jersey aggregation is that five of
the starting ten are Baltimoreans,
Andy Taylor and Joe King from
Boys Latin School play on the close
attack, Billy Lynn from Gilman is
at second attack; Henry Thomas
from Gilman plays defense; and
Bucky Turner, also from Gilman,
takes care of the nets. Five or six
more local boys are on the squad.
All of the first five named with the
exception of Thomas were former
All State prep school stars.
The Blue Jays are pointing for
this game, and the coaching staff,
Mallonee,
and
Morrill,
Messrs.
Schmeisser have been working the
whole squad very hard. It is problematical whether four regulars,
Nicholson, Spilman, Nance, and
Buck, will be able to play. Of the
four, Nance has the best chance. In
has
Morrill
meantime, Dr
the
switched Dick Green from center to
out home and brought up Charles
Thomas for the inhome position in
order to complete with John Enders
the close attack. Bob Gosnell filled in
the center position and Jack
Williams replaced Buck on the defense. Despite the fact that these
injuries have riddled the attack, recent scrimmages have not shown any
decrease in its power.
Offsetting the news of injuries
came the information that John
Tolson, JHU All American of 1938,
has returned to action. He will be
able to play five minutes in each
quarter against Princeton, a little
more time per quarter against St
Johns, and the whole game against
Maryland. Because he is not in shape
and has not worked with the defense, his presence in the line-up
may not increase its strength a
great deal. But the last two games
he will have the condition and will
have been accustomed to this defense. Freddy Buck and Rip Hewitt
please note.

Varsity softballers
shut-out Maryland
The J H U varsity softball team
played its first game of the season
Tuesday aftrenoon at College Park,
Md, where they shut out the U of
Maryland, 6-0. The team is composed
of both fraternity and non-fraternity
men.
The battlers for the Jays found M
Cord on the mound and Pressman on
the receiving end. Robinson, first
base; Rossett, second base; Fehr,
short stop, and Sullivan, third base,
rounded out the infield while Butt,
Zavertnick and Grey patroled the
outfield.
The Jays got off to an early tworun lead in the first and added one in
the third, two more in the fourth, and
their final tally came in the fifth.
The Marylanders could do very
little with the slants of McCord,
whose fast ball and change of pace
kept the opposing batters off balance. McCord pitched no hit, no run
ball until the seventh, when with one
out he let up and allowed the one
and only hit of the game off him.
His mates gave him good support
and hit hard and often to win .he
game handily.
The next varsity softball game
will be played tomorrow at Homewood against George Washington U.

Speaking
150 students, the largest audience
ever to assemble in Levering hall's
Sherwood room in the memory of
undergraduates, Dr Broadus Mitchell
urged Hopkins students to investigate and judge social conditions for
themselves.
Only the individual work of students, he stressed, can be of value in
the nation's future progress. While
orthodox material and opinions may
be studied by the student, he declared
they should serve only as a general
background of knowledge.
This was one of Dr Mitchell's last
public appearances in connection with
the university. He resigned his post
of professor of economics last month,
thus ending a quarter-century career with the Hopkins.
Dr Mitchell traced the evolution of
higher education in America in its
broad general trends. Beginning with
the founding of the Hopkins in 1867,
he emphasized that private colleges
and universities were in the liberal
vanguard then, while the state-supported institutions struggled for existence.

colonel made a farewell speech, expressing sorrow "at leaving such an
intelligent, friendly group of students."

West Point in 1911.

Shall brithers be for a' that."
Thus spoke Bobby Burns at the
dawn of the 19th century, little realizing that 143 years after his death
there was to come into the world an
instrument, a great invention, that
will do more to make men all over the
world brothers than the spirit of his
own "man to man" poetry. Television is that great invention and
fittingly it was inaugurated in this
country at the City of Tomorrow with
the address of our President.
In these shivering times it's mighty
hard to conceive of anything making
men feel like brothers. The radio
might have done it, but the voice is
not enough to establish a real contact with a foreigner; you just give
him a look at you, let him see that
you're not much different than he is
and pretty soon he'll begin to understand you. Before television, all he
could hear was some gibberish tongue
which more than likely sounded distasteful to him, but once he sees you

moving around, though he doesn't understand what you have to say, your
actions will speak for themselves.
This cub reporter hopes that television will broaden the vision of peace
rather than merely view the war
abroad!
